title: Color interpolators return color instances.
body: Fixes #1029. Previously, these interpolators returned RGB hexadecimal strings, as the intent was for the color to be used to set attributes and styles. However, since #333, all colors return RGB hexadecimal strings when coerced to a string, so we can get the equivalent behavior by returning a color instance rather than a string. Returning a color instance is also more useful in the case where additional color manipulation (such as brighter/darker) is desired.

title: By default, enter-insert before updating sibling.
body: Fixes #744. This implements a default _before_ selector such that when entering elements are inserted (e.g., `selection.enter().insert("div")`), they are inserted before the next following sibling in the update selection, if any. This change does not affect the behavior of append, so as to preserve backwards-compatibility, and likewise does not affect the behavior of insert on non-enter selections.

title: Use linear segments for basis interpolation ends.
body: The first and last segment of a line interpolated using basis (B-spline) interpolation are necessarily linear. WebKit appears to have a bug where linear Bézier segments do not compute tangents correctly (presumably because the control points are coincident with an end point, and the angle of a zero-length vector is undefined). We can workaround this browser bug by using linear segments for the start and end.

title: Accept function for selection append and insert.
body:
Like selection.select, selection.append and selection.insert can now accept a function which returns a node. This facilitates appending or inserting elements whose name is computed from data, or appending elements that were created previously (such as removed elements or elements from a pool).

There has been [much discussion](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/pull/732#issuecomment-7436280) regarding whether the function should return the name of the element or the element itself. Returning a name is less work for the caller, but only supports creating new elements. Returning a name is more consistent with how D3 defines attribute values, but D3 does not allow attribute names to be specified as functions. So, it seemed better to opt for consistency with selection.select and selection.selectAll, which accept functions that return elements. Of course, you can still pass a function to selection.select, selection.selectAll or selection.each to accomplish the same thing, but using selection.append is more intuitive.

Related #4 #311 #724 #732 #734 #961 #1031 #1271.

title: Allow pack.radius to be specified as constant.
Remove axis.tickSubdivide. Fixes #1115.
body: An alternative to #1350.

title: Replace axis.tickSubdivide with axis.minorTicks. Fixes #1115.
body:
I’m not sure yet if this is a good idea, but it does seem more flexible than subdividing ticks in the axis that were computed by the scale. The problem with the simpler fix of #1115 is that the axis can’t force the scale to generate two extra major ticks—those ticks could be irregularly-spaced, as is the case with a time scale.

So, rather than trying to subdivide ticks uniformly, the axis exposes a way of creating minor ticks. For example, you could have major ticks using d3.time.weeks, and minor ticks using d3.time.days. Any minor tick that is also a major tick is only displayed as a major tick. 

One weakness with this approach is that it assumes there is a scale.ticks method, so there’s no way to create minor ticks for an ordinal scale or other scale that doesn’t support generating ticks. Likewise, although you can specify major ticks explicitly using axis.tickValues, I haven’t exposed an axis.minorTickValues method.

This pull request retains the axis.tickSubdivide method as a no-op, so that existing code will not break. However, this means you need to update code to call axis.minorTicks if you want minor ticks displayed. It’s possible in some cases to generate suitable minor tick arguments, and thus have better backwards-compatibility, but since it’s not possible in all cases this seems like a reasonable option. Alternatively we could defer this until 4.0?

Lastly, my other reservation is whether the axis needs an explicit concept of major and minor ticks at all. It seems like clients could specify only major ticks, and then use post-selection to mark a subset of them as minor ticks.

title: Limit transform interpolation to transition.attr.
body:
D3’s transform interpolator is designed for SVG transforms; unlike CSS3 transforms, SVG transforms do not have units and are limited to 2D. This commit limits transform interpolation to transition.attr, so that it only applies to SVG transforms and not CSS3 transforms which are assigned via style. Thus, if transition.style is used to interpolate the transform style, the default string interpolator will now be used.

Note that string interpolation of CSS3 transforms is still likely to break; you should use CSS3 transitions instead. Fixes #1323.

title: Add currency support to d3.format. Fixes #777.
body:
You can now prefix the locale’s currency symbol. For example:

``` js
d3.format("+$,.2f")(-2.5e5) // -$250,000.00
```

This implementation is limited in that it does not support currencies where the symbol should appear after the value (e.g., "250,000.00 €" as in fr_FR). And d3.format currently only supports a single locale. But it’s a start.

title: Fix clip for closed polygons.
body:
This pull request fixes a long standing bug (#443) by making polygon.clip work on closed polygons; previously it only worked on open polygons. The other polygon methods, area and centroid, already work on both open and closed polygons.

This pull request also changes d3.geom.polygon to use a prototype rather than creating every method as a closure. This will potentially break callers that assumed polygon methods were bound to the object instance, but this was never documented as an API guarantee so I am comfortable making this change in a patch release. (Also, the majority of examples using polygon.clip should now be using the more-convenient voronoi.clipExtent.)

title: Implement inertial drag
body:
Please see the example: http://bl.ocks.org/pjanik/5872514
Recently I needed such feature and implemented it in my application, but then I came up with the idea that it can be easily generalized. Inertial drag is quite popular nowadays.

I'm creating pull request so you can easily review the code, but of course I'm open for discussion. 
Do you find it useful?

Note that I'm not very familiar with d3 codebase, so I'm happy to fix implementation details, style, add some tests etc. in case of need.

title: Generalize suppression of undesired default behaviors when dragging.
body: Fixes #1321.

title: Use angular, not projected, distance for sampling threshold.
body: Fixes #1332.

title: Adds tests for d3.svg.diagonal
body: Simple test coverage for d3.svg.diagonal, in the style of existing tests.  Addresses #550.  More missing tests to come.

title: rename components.json to bower.json
body: in case of there is a warning when `bower install d3` :)

title: Optional accessor function for dsv.format[Rows].
body:
This makes the formatting API fully symmetric with parsing.

@paulsputer needed to format a subset of an object’s properties for each row, so I suggested using csv.formatRows(rows.map(…)).  However, this does not output field headings, and it would be cleaner to use csv.format(rows, accessor) for symmetry with parsing rather than having to roll your own.

title: Add transition.size.
body: Fixes #1327; supersedes #1328.

title: add transition.size
body: fixes #1327

title: Restore preventDefault, but use tabindex to focus the parent element.
body:
Work-in-progress. Supersedes #1322. Should fix #1321 #1288 #1099.

Tasks:
- [ ] Applying the drag behavior, zoom behavior or brush should set the tabindex attribute and outline style on the nearest HTML ancestor element (the ownerSVGElement when used within SVG, and the current element when used within HTML).
- [ ] If the tabindex attribute is already set, it should be preserved? What about the outline style? It might be safe to ignore this possibility.
- [x] The mousedown event should be cancelled (using preventDefault and stopPropagation).
- [x] The touchstart event should _not_ be cancelled for the drag behavior, as this disables draggable links. (Canceling mousedown does not prevent click, but canceling touchstart effectively does.)

title: Stop event propagation for {brush,drag,zoom}.
body:
This allows behaviours and d3.svg.brush to be used together easily.

Also, only bind relevant event listeners on brush touchstart; a
mousemove event was being triggered on mobile Safari causing the brush
to jump briefly on touchstart, e.g. when viewing:

  http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/raw/1667367/

Fixes #1321.

title: brush.clamp: return null if there are no scales.
body:
Similarly, if there are no scales, setting a clamp does nothing.

For consistency with brush.extent.

title: Fixes d3_time_interval to return regular time intervals
body:
The d3_time_interval function used "number" in order to implement steps,
which led to incorrect behavior. For example, the "number" function for
months returned date.getMonth(), which is 0 for January, hence if the
step input to range was greater than 12, an array containing all the
January 1 dates between start and end would be returned. Because number
was only used (incorrectly) in the range function I've gone through the
time implementations and removed the specific cases.

title: Fix winding order detection for degenerate zero-area polygons.
body: Fixes #1305. /cc @jasondavies

title: Fix winding order detection for degenerate zero-area polygons.
body: Fixes #1305. /cc @jasondavies
